Plus there's always different styles of racing. Pure racing, knockout races, drift races, can go with destruction derby in some games as well.
And driving games are the same thing. Instead of being more arcade-y, it adds better physics, better damage impacts, more accurate damage models and vehicle effects, better driving AI, etc etc

im rather familiar with the process of making games and Racing seems to me to be one of the easier- its a lot easier to model cars than people for one
the car models isn't the hard part
far as I know, it's the physics that's the hard part
It is. But getting physics engines working properly for wear and tear during a race is harder, along with determining grip levels for certain ranges of heat on the tires
Brake wear during a race, fuel consumption per how much the pedal is actually being used
but the physics arent that big of an issue either because you just fake it

if you fake it, then it's not a good simulator.
bull crap

you have to fake everything in a game
you cant "Simulate real world physics" perfectly in a game
They're running Gran Turismo simulation settings past F1 drivers who are authenticating its physics as being top notch.
you have to fake every part people will notice
All games are faked by that logic.
they are
xD
The point of a simulator is to get it as absolutely close to realism as possible.
you dont do that by making the game PHYSICS better though
you do it by making the outcome the same
Your logic makes no sense to me
omg
The physics determine the outcome.
wait.. how would you change the outcome without changing the physics? O.o
the physics arent physics- games dont run on the rules of the universe
You're right, they run on a simulation of the rules of the universe, recreated as realistically as possible, assuming that's what they're aiming for.
So, logically speaking, if your physics engine is working properly, performing an action across a section of road will produce the same results in-game as it will in reality.
So, in effect, yes, your physics engine is looking to reproduce a result, but, it's also in place so that if a different input is used, then it changes the result.
It has to be close enough for real people to play and say it feels like it's driving on a real road. And driving simulators are doing so

Well, at that point it wouldn't be a game, and would be a true simulator, and would be used literally by those who do what it simulates irl
Which iirc, Ferrari at least does have an actual simulator that their F1 racers use
simulators cut corners too - the difference is they keep more faults to simulate more real world issues

for example- wind turbulence in a Flight simulator isnt a complex algorithm determined by how you are flying - its based on a set of random values that are impacted by a chart on they set weather parameters, they didnt simulate air
but yeah- my ranting was mostly me taking my Trolling too far and then getting triggered by "Real World Game Physics" :P
lol

It's a fair point on some issues, but I believe they ARE attempting to get as realistic results as possible. But yeah, you're right, trying to do 1:1 simulation would require a HELL of a lot of processing power.

its not like Cloud twirling around a sword 3 times his body weight like a baton
